{
  "conversation": [
    {
      "turn_id": 1,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:10",
      "text": "Hello, I’m one of the medicine residents. I understand you came in because of chest pain. Can you tell me in your own words what the pain felt like and when it started?",
      "evidence_eids": ["ADM#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 2,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:11",
      "text": "It woke me up two nights ago. It was right in the middle of my chest, kind of sharp and worse when I took a deep breath. It didn’t go down my arm or anything. It just stayed there for hours until they gave me a Percocet in the ER and then it went away.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 3,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:15",
      "text": "Thank you. Any shortness of breath, sweating, nausea, or vomiting with the pain?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 4,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:16",
      "text": "No, none of that. No trouble breathing, no sweating, no throwing up. It just hurt when I breathed in.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 5,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:20",
      "text": "In the emergency room your vital signs were stable and your oxygen level was normal. Your EKG looked okay, and your chest X‑ray didn’t show any pneumonia or fluid around the lungs. A CT scan of your chest also ruled out a blood clot in the lungs and any aortic problem. So far, this makes a heart attack or pulmonary embolism much less likely.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001", "RAD#000002", "LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000003"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 6,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:21",
      "text": "So it’s not my heart? That’s what I was scared about.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 7,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:23",
      "text": "Given your normal EKG, the CT scan, and your blood tests, we don’t see signs of a heart attack or a clot. Your troponin, a heart enzyme, is a bit elevated, but in people with kidney failure like you that can be chronically high, and your CK‑MB, another heart marker, stayed flat, which is reassuring.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000003", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000018", "LAB#000025", "LAB#000028", "LAB#000029"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 8,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:26",
      "text": "You also mentioned trouble swallowing and poor appetite since the day before you came in. Can you describe that? Does food get stuck, or is it painful when you swallow?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 9,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:27",
      "text": "It hurts going down, like a burning and soreness behind my breastbone. I haven’t really wanted to eat since yesterday.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 10,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:30",
      "text": "Given that, we’re thinking your pain may be coming from your esophagus or stomach rather than your heart. We’ll start a stomach acid medicine and a numbing/antacid mixture to see if that helps, and we’ll ask the GI team to evaluate you. We’ll also keep you on your usual dialysis schedule since you’re due for hemodialysis today.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000023", "PHARM#000025", "PHARM#000036", "PHARM#000057", "PHARM#000060", "PX#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 11,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:31",
      "text": "Okay. As long as you can still get me to dialysis. I go Monday, Wednesday, Friday.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000003", "DX#000011"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 12,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:33",
      "text": "Yes, we’ll make sure you get dialysis here on your usual schedule. We’ll also continue your sevelamer and cinacalcet for your kidney disease and parathyroid issues.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000003", "DX#000004", "PX#000001", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000009", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 13,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H+01:00",
      "text": "I’m your nurse tonight. Your blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen look good. If you have any more chest discomfort or trouble swallowing, please call me right away. I’ll bring your pain medicine and stomach cocktail shortly.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000016", "PHARM#000023", "PHARM#000027"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 14,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+01:01",
      "text": "Thank you. My chest doesn’t hurt right now, but my muscles and joints ache like usual.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 15,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:30",
      "text": "Good morning. I’m the attending on the medicine service. I see your chest pain has resolved. On exam your heart sounds are regular, lungs are clear, and there’s no tenderness over your chest wall. That fits with what we’re seeing on your tests.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001", "RAD#000002", "LAB#000015", "LAB#000019", "LAB#000023", "LAB#000024"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 16,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:31",
      "text": "Yeah, the chest pain is gone. It’s mostly the swallowing and my usual body pains now.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 17,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:35",
      "text": "Your blood work this morning shows your hemoglobin is a bit low at around 9, which is similar to your usual anemia from kidney disease. Your white count is slightly low, and your electrolytes and calcium are okay for you. We’ll continue your folic acid and epoetin with dialysis.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000004", "LAB#000005", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000011", "LAB#000012", "LAB#000015", "LAB#000019", "DX#000010", "PHARM#000012", "PHARM#000019", "PHARM#000042", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 18,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:38",
      "text": "Because of your HIV and the swallowing pain, we’re concerned about possible esophagitis or gastritis. We’ve started omeprazole and will have GI do an upper endoscopy in the next couple of days. For now, we’ll keep you on a soft diet as tolerated.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "PHARM#000057", "PHARM#000060", "PX#000002", "RAD#000003", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 19,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:39",
      "text": "Okay. I’m not on my HIV meds right now. Are you going to restart those?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]

    {
      "turn_id": 20,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:42",
      "text": "You’ve been off HAART because of past adherence issues. Our infectious disease colleagues know you and will see you again. During this stay we’re restarting your prophylaxis with Bactrim and azithromycin to prevent infections like PCP and MAC. Restarting full HIV therapy will be coordinated with your outpatient ID doctor, especially since omeprazole can interact with some HIV meds.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "PHARM#000006", "PHARM#000024", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 21,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:43",
      "text": "I understand. I’ll talk to them, but I want to make sure I can actually take everything this time.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 22,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:10",
      "text": "You’ve just spiked a fever to a little over 102. We’ve drawn blood cultures and started IV vancomycin and cefepime as ordered. Let me know if you feel worse—shortness of breath, chest pain, or chills.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "PHARM#000028", "PHARM#000030", "PHARM#000031", "MICRO#000001", "MICRO#000002", "MICRO#000024"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 23,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:11",
      "text": "I feel really cold and achy. Is this from my line?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 24,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 08:30",
      "text": "This morning your fever from last night is documented, and your blood cultures from that time have now grown coagulase‑negative staph, a skin bacteria that often infects dialysis catheters. We think your hemodialysis line is the likely source of your bloodstream infection.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000001", "DX#000005", "DX#000011", "MICRO#000001", "MICRO#000002", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 25,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 08:31",
      "text": "If it’s the line, does that mean you have to take it out? I’ve already had so many fistulas fail.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]

    {
      "turn_id": 26,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 08:35",
      "text": "We’re very aware that your access is limited. But because you’re still having fevers despite vancomycin, and the cultures show bacteria that like to stick to plastic, the safest way to clear the infection is to remove this catheter. We’ll coordinate with nephrology and interventional radiology to remove it and then place a new temporary dialysis line, likely in your groin, after a short ‘line holiday.’",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000001", "DX#000005", "PX#000003", "PX#000004", "RAD#000004", "RAD#000005", "PHARM#000032", "PHARM#000037", "PHARM#000048", "DS#000001"]

      "text": "I’m from the infectious disease team. Your blood cultures show coagulase‑negative staph that’s sensitive to vancomycin. We agree with continuing IV vancomycin and stopping cefepime once we’re sure there’s no gram‑negative infection. Because of persistent fevers, we support removing the current dialysis catheter and then treating with several weeks of vancomycin, dosed with dialysis.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000001", "DX#000005", "PHARM#000028", "PHARM#000030", "PHARM#000032", "PHARM#000034", "PHARM#000048", "PHARM#000050", "PHARM#000063", "PHARM#000064", "MICRO#000009", "MICRO#000010", "MICRO#000011", "MICRO#000012", "MICRO#000013", "MICRO#000014", "MICRO#000015", "MICRO#000016", "DS#000001"]

      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 11:05",
      "text": "Yes. The plan is for you to receive vancomycin with your dialysis sessions for several weeks after discharge. The nephrology team will follow levels and adjust the dose. You may also receive antibiotic ‘locks’ in the new catheter to prevent re‑infection.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000032", "PHARM#000063", "PHARM#000072", "PHARM#000076", "PHARM#000079", "DS#000001"]

    {

We suggest avoiding very spicy or acidic foods and continuing the acid‑suppressing medicine. Your primary team will also watch for any medication interactions when HIV therapy is restarted, since omeprazole can conflict with some regimens.",

Because of that, interventional radiology plans to place a tunneled femoral dialysis catheter in your right groin today.",

The femoral catheter is being placed after a short line holiday and while you’re on appropriate antibiotics, so it’s an accepted approach when upper‑body veins are blocked. We’ll monitor closely for any new signs of infection.",

      "text": "Your new tunneled femoral dialysis catheter was placed successfully this morning. The tip sits in the right atrium and is ready for use. We’ll coordinate with dialysis to resume your treatments through this line.",

      "speaker": "CONSULT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay10 09:30",
      "text": "From an HIV standpoint, your CD4 count is low and you’ve had PCP in the past. We strongly recommend staying on Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin twice weekly. We’ll defer restarting full HAART to your outpatient ID doctor, but it’s important to plan for that soon.",

For the groin catheter, avoid strenuous activity, keep the dressing clean and dry, and call if you notice redness, swelling, drainage, or fevers.",

  "end_of_admission_summary": {
    "relative_discharge_time": "H+20018",
    "one_paragraph_summary": "During this admission, a middle‑aged woman with advanced HIV/AIDS off HAART, ESRD on thrice‑weekly hemodialysis, chronic anemia, and chronic pain presented with pleuritic substernal chest pain and new odynophagia. Initial evaluation showed stable vital signs, a normal EKG, and chest imaging without acute cardiopulmonary pathology; CTA chest ruled out pulmonary embolism and aortic dissection, and serial cardiac enzymes showed modest troponin elevation with flat CK‑MB, interpreted as non‑ischemic in the setting of ESRD. She subsequently developed high fevers and was found to have coagulase‑negative staphylococcal bacteremia, attributed to her tunneled hemodialysis catheter; broad‑spectrum antibiotics were started, then narrowed to vancomycin, and the infected line was removed after multidisciplinary discussion. Because venography demonstrated bilateral central subclavian occlusions, a tunneled right femoral hemodialysis catheter was placed for ongoing access. GI evaluation for chest discomfort and dysphagia included an upper GI barium study, which was normal, and EGD, which showed gastritis and duodenitis; she was started on omeprazole with symptomatic improvement. She also developed a small left lower lobe pneumonia on chest radiograph, treated transiently with cefepime until radiographic resolution and persistently negative cultures. Throughout the stay she continued sevelamer, cinacalcet, epoetin, vitamin D analogs, and renal vitamins for ESRD and secondary hyperparathyroidism, and Bactrim and azithromycin prophylaxis were restarted for HIV. By discharge she was afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulating independently, tolerating diet with improved odynophagia, and had negative follow‑up blood cultures; she was discharged home with services, to continue vancomycin with dialysis and her revised outpatient medication regimen.",

      "evidence_eids": ["ADM#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 2,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:11",

      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 3,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:15",
      "text": "Thank you. Any shortness of breath, sweating, nausea, or vomiting with the pain?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 4,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:16",
      "text": "No, none of that. No trouble breathing, no sweating, no throwing up. It just hurt when I breathed in.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 5,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:20",
      "text": "In the emergency room your vital signs were stable and your oxygen level was normal. Your EKG looked okay, and your chest X‑ray didn’t show any pneumonia or fluid around the lungs. A CT scan of your chest also ruled out a blood clot in the lungs and any aortic problem. So far, this makes a heart attack or pulmonary embolism much less likely.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001", "RAD#000002", "LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000003"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 6,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:21",
      "text": "So it’s not my heart? That’s what I was scared about.",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 7,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:23",
      "text": "Given your normal EKG, the CT scan, and your blood tests, we don’t see signs of a heart attack or a clot. Your troponin, a heart enzyme, is a bit elevated, but in people with kidney failure like you that can be chronically high, and your CK‑MB, another heart marker, stayed flat, which is reassuring.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000003", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000018", "LAB#000025", "LAB#000028", "LAB#000029"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 8,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:26",
      "text": "You also mentioned trouble swallowing and poor appetite since the day before you came in. Can you describe that? Does food get stuck, or is it painful when you swallow?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 9,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:27",
      "text": "It hurts going down, like a burning and soreness behind my breastbone. I haven’t really wanted to eat since yesterday.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 10,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:30",
      "text": "Given that, we’re thinking your pain may be coming from your esophagus or stomach rather than your heart. We’ll start a stomach acid medicine and a numbing/antacid mixture to see if that helps, and we’ll ask the GI team to evaluate you. We’ll also keep you on your usual dialysis schedule since you’re due for hemodialysis today.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000023", "PHARM#000025", "PHARM#000036", "PHARM#000057", "PHARM#000060", "PX#000001", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 11,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:31",
      "text": "Okay. As long as you can still get me to dialysis. I go Monday, Wednesday, Friday.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000003", "DX#000011"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 12,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:33",
      "text": "Yes, we’ll make sure you get dialysis here on your usual schedule. We’ll also continue your sevelamer and cinacalcet for your kidney disease and parathyroid issues.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000003", "DX#000004", "PX#000001", "PHARM#000008", "PHARM#000009", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 13,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H+01:00",
      "text": "I’m your nurse tonight. Your blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen look good. If you have any more chest discomfort or trouble swallowing, please call me right away. I’ll bring your pain medicine and stomach cocktail shortly.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000016", "PHARM#000023", "PHARM#000027"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 14,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+01:01",
      "text": "Thank you. My chest doesn’t hurt right now, but my muscles and joints ache like usual.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 15,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:30",
      "text": "Good morning. I’m the attending on the medicine service. I see your chest pain has resolved. On exam your heart sounds are regular, lungs are clear, and there’s no tenderness over your chest wall. That fits with what we’re seeing on your tests.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001", "RAD#000002", "LAB#000015", "LAB#000019", "LAB#000023", "LAB#000024"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 16,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:31",
      "text": "Yeah, the chest pain is gone. It’s mostly the swallowing and my usual body pains now.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 17,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:35",
      "text": "Your blood work this morning shows your hemoglobin is a bit low at around 9, which is similar to your usual anemia from kidney disease. Your white count is slightly low, and your electrolytes and calcium are okay for you. We’ll continue your folic acid and epoetin with dialysis.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000004", "LAB#000005", "LAB#000008", "LAB#000011", "LAB#000012", "LAB#000015", "LAB#000019", "DX#000010", "PHARM#000012", "PHARM#000019", "PHARM#000042", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 18,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:38",
      "text": "Because of your HIV and the swallowing pain, we’re concerned about possible esophagitis or gastritis. We’ve started omeprazole and will have GI do an upper endoscopy in the next couple of days. For now, we’ll keep you on a soft diet as tolerated.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "PHARM#000057", "PHARM#000060", "PX#000002", "RAD#000003", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 19,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:39",
      "text": "Okay. I’m not on my HIV meds right now. Are you going to restart those?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 20,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:42",
      "text": "You’ve been off HAART because of past adherence issues. Our infectious disease colleagues know you and will see you again. During this stay we’re restarting your prophylaxis with Bactrim and azithromycin to prevent infections like PCP and MAC. Restarting full HIV therapy will be coordinated with your outpatient ID doctor, especially since omeprazole can interact with some HIV meds.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000002", "PHARM#000006", "PHARM#000024", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 21,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 08:43",
      "text": "I understand. I’ll talk to them, but I want to make sure I can actually take everything this time.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 22,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:10",
      "text": "You’ve just spiked a fever to a little over 102. We’ve drawn blood cultures and started IV vancomycin and cefepime as ordered. Let me know if you feel worse—shortness of breath, chest pain, or chills.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "PHARM#000028", "PHARM#000030", "PHARM#000031", "MICRO#000001", "MICRO#000002", "MICRO#000024"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 23,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 03:11",
      "text": "I feel really cold and achy. Is this from my line?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 24,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 08:30",
      "text": "This morning your fever from last night is documented, and your blood cultures from that time have now grown coagulase‑negative staph, a skin bacteria that often infects dialysis catheters. We think your hemodialysis line is the likely source of your bloodstream infection.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DX#000001", "DX#000005", "DX#000011", "MICRO#000001", "MICRO#000002", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 25,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 08:31",
      "text": "If it’s the line, does that mean you have to take it out? I’ve already had so many fistulas fail.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 26,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay2 08:35",
      "text": "We’re very aware that your access is limited.
